awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Developing servomotor actuators using advances in metallic additive manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of electric motors for higher torque position control actuators used in robotic and industrial automation systems. The worldwide market for position control actuators is forecast to reach $16 billion by 2026. This market growth is associated with the transition to Industry 4.0 methods that seek improved efficiency and faster adaptation to variable market demands by developing streamlined processes in product development and delivery technologies. Achieving the benefits of Industry 4.0 practices involves extensive use of advanced electric motor controls and actuators to connect manufacturing systems through digital communication networks. In addition, the electrification of transportation systems such as autonomous vehicles, electric aircraft, and railways are further increasing the demand for position control actuators and their associated control electronics. The proposed technology may increase the ability of industries to expand manufacturing capacity in the US. Further, electric motor actuators may enable a much larger increase in economic development associated with emerging markets for advanced robotics, autonomous vehicles, aircraft, and transportation electrification.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of copper additive manufacturing technologies that enable the design of new types of electrical machinery including electric motor position control actuators. These types of actuators are used for precise control of position, velocity and acceleration in robotics and industrial automation equipment. The designs enabled by the proposed copper additive manufacturing allows sensor and electronic control functions to be integrated into a single modular device. In addition, the proposed technology provides greater than 40% more torque and power density compared to existing electrical actuators, eliminates cables and wiring between electric motor actuators and control electronics by integrating these into a single assembly, and eliminates separate position sensing devices using magnetic and electrical structures that provide dual functionality of torque production with position and velocity sensing. These proposed features may result in reduced size and weight while achieving increased reliability in extreme temperature, vibration, and liquid environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The increasing adoption of electric vehicles, drones, robotics, and industrial automation equipment has highlighted the need for electric machines and actuators that possess greater torque density and maximized energy efficiency. The research team has been developing servomotor actuators that have greater than 30% higher torque and increased power densities compared to existing products. Servomotor actuators are used for precise control of angular and linear position, velocity and acceleration in robotics and industrial automation equipment. The goal of this research is to provide new products for the expanding global servomotor market.

The intellectual merit of this project is based on employing a novel hybrid copper and ferromagnetic metal additive manufacturing process that results in greater than 30% increase in motor torque using a novel geometry that provides dual functionality of position and velocity measurement. In order to produce this technology in a low-cost environment, the research team employed a metal fused filament fabrication (MFFF) process for copper and ferromagnetic materials. MFFF has the advantage of eliminating the safety risks associated with traditional methods such as direct metal laser sintering. In addition, MFFF is approximately 10 times less expensive compared to other metal additive manufacturing technologies.

The broader impacts of this research include the benefits offered to the $2.7 billion (2023) market for servomotors in the US. The worldwide servomotor market is forecast to grow at a 4% compound annual growth rate to reach $16 billion by 2026. This market growth is associated with the transition to Industry 4.0 processes that seek improved efficiency and faster adaptation to variable market demands by developing streamlined product development and delivery technologies. Industrial automation involves extensive use of advanced servomotors to connect manufacturing systems through computer networks. The electrification of transportation systems such as autonomous vehicles, electric aircraft, and railways are further increasing the demand for servomotors and their associated control electronics.

The I-Corps program enabled the research team to gain valuable insight into the need for improved servomotor technologies and discovery of potential customer segments. The new technology, when commercialized with knowledge and skills acquired through the I-Corps program, will ultimately increase the ability of US-based industries to expand domestic manufacturing capacity. The economic multiplier effect of the domestic servomotor market will enable a much larger increase in economic development associated with emerging markets in transportation electrification, advanced robotics, autonomous vehicles, and industrial automation.


Last Modified: 05/31/2024
Modified by: Roy Mccann
